Parameters

  • tol â€“ float Threshold below which two matrix elements are considered equal.

orquestra.quantum.utils.compare_unitary(u1: numpy.ndarray, u2: numpy.ndarray, tol: float = 1e-15) → bool#

Compares two unitary operators to see if they are equal to within a phase.

Parameters

  • u1 (numpy.ndarray) â€“ First unitary operator.

  • u2 (numpy.ndarray) â€“ Second unitary operator.

  • tol (float) â€“ Threshold below which two matrix elements are considered equal.

Returns

True if the unitaries are equal to within the tolerance, ignoring

differences in global phase.

Return type

bool

orquestra.quantum.utils.sample_from_probability_distribution(probability_distribution: dict, n_samples: int) → collections.Counter#

Samples events from a discrete probability distribution

Parameters

  • probabilty_distribution â€“ The discrete probability distribution to be used

  • dictionary (for sampling. This should be a) â€“

  • n_samples (int) â€“ The number of samples desired

Returns

A dictionary of the outcomes sampled. The key values are the things be sampled and values are how many times those things appeared in the sampling

orquestra.quantum.utils.save_nmeas_estimate(nmeas: float, nterms: int, filename: orquestra.quantum.typing.AnyPath, frame_meas: numpy.ndarray = None) → None#

Save an estimate of the number of measurements to a file

Parameters

  • nmeas â€“ total number of measurements for epsilon = 1.0

  • nterms â€“ number of terms (groups) in the objective function

  • frame_meas â€“ A list of the number of measurements per frame for epsilon = 1.0

orquestra.quantum.utils.load_nmeas_estimate(filename: orquestra.quantum.typing.AnyPath) → Tuple[float, int, numpy.ndarray]#

Load an estimate of the number of measurements from a file.

Parameters

filename â€“ the name of the file

Returns

number of measurements for epsilon = 1.0 nterms: number of terms in the hamiltonian frame_meas: frame measurements (number of measurements per group)

Return type

nmeas

orquestra.quantum.utils.scale_and_discretize(values: Iterable[float], total: int) → List[int]#

Convert a list of floats to a list of integers such that the total equals a given value and the ratios of elements are approximately preserved.

Parameters

  • values â€“ The list of floats to be scaled and discretized.

  • total â€“ The desired total which the resulting values should sum to.

Returns

A list of integers whose sum is equal to the given total, where the

ratios of the list elements are approximately equal to the ratios of the input list elements.

orquestra.quantum.utils.get_ordered_list_of_bitstrings(num_qubits: int) → List[str]#

Create list of binary strings corresponding to 2^num_qubits integers and save them in ascending order.

Parameters

num_qubits â€“ number of binary digits in each bitstring

Returns

The ordered bitstring representations of the integers
